Paul

I like this side. I just wrote another letter, because i wanna say that the MiG-21 was used by more countries than any other fighter. It is still used today by a couple of countries. And I dont think it will go out of service for a while, because India has just made plans to buy either MiG-21 or Su-17. They will choose one of these. Probably the MiG-21, because it is more agile. And i also want everyone to know that just because Western or NATO's pilots shot down MiG-21's over Vietnam(with Vietnamese pilots flying the MiG) that dosent mean tha MiG's suck. It dosent only takes the fighters manuveribility to win a dogfight, but also the pilots skill. And i know that almost any pilot from any country is more skilled then the North Vietnames.

Barry A. Miller, Lt Col , USAF (Ret)

Would like to know more about what author thought of the MiG-21bis/R-3R combination. Even though a person occasionally sees pictures of the "AA-2c Radar ATOLL" on the MiG-21, one never hears much about if it was an effective system or to what extent MiG-21 pilots trained to use it. The apparently similar AIM-9C semi-active radar homing (SARH)version of the US Sidewinder never was much a success on the F-8D/E/H/J Crusader, and had very little operational use.

James Rammstein

Thanks a lot for this amazing site. The Mig 21 is a legend and obviously it is unavoidable to state that the Mig 21 was really superior to the F 4 Phantom, which was by the way also a good birdy. But shotdowns are proof enough the Mig 21 was superior. Imagine today a dogfight between a Mig - 29 and a F-16, no question the wing with the red star would win! Sad that the Breakdown for 10 years slowed down the production but I'm still confident that the russians still have the better fighters. Look at the Stealth/Bomber which was shot down in the Kosovo Crisis, am sorry americans how could that happen with your invisible heralded Bomber? Looking forward for further news and please keep up and develop this site which is pretty good. Tschau zaeme James

AMH1 Frank A. Pasallo, USN(Retired)

I'm highly interested in Soviet Aircraft. It nice for you to pulish this informative page, thank you. I was a former F14, S3A, P3, SH3, ES3A technician. I loved them all. The Rusians have always fascinated me with the brilliant aircrat they were motivated to design becuase of the cold war. I would never want to go to war with them, becuase it would be the last. Just brief yourself on thier sturggle during Hitlar's war machine. I wish to bore you now with one of my storys. Almost 20 years ago, when I was just a young Airmen out of the navy's "A" school, I was assigned to Fighter Squadron One Two Four (VF-124), since decommissioned. I remember during one of my watches topside in the administration levels, I would sometimes have to go the the pilots ready room. There on the wall are some pictures that are forever etched in my mind, and recall them vividly as if I was looking at them yesterday. It was a series of about five 8"X10" black and white pictures forming a collage on the wall. In two seperate tours at VF124, each 3 years in length during a span of about 10 years those pictures were never taken down from the wall. The pictures were arrianged in a pyrimid fashion. Of the two top ones , the one on the left represented a frontol view of a early delta wing series Mig looming forward aggressively with its its long probe thrusting forward beyond its gaping intake, like a lance. Next to the Mig, in the right forgeround of the pictue , was a standing figure in a silver flight suit, his legs slightly spread and his head turned sideways, looking up in the proud fashion and military demeanor that is instilled in the Soviet Military. The caption under that photograph read" The Soviet Fighter Pilot". With his machine the pilot in that picture represented to the young American Pilots what they must someday go up against. Even with th e sophisticated F-14 Tomcats of the day, I would look at that picture and say to myself, " it is not going to be easy" Thank you
